äºŒåä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œç§¦å¤§å¤«æœ‰ç§èˆ‡æ¥šå¤ªå­é¬¬ï¼Œæ¥šå¤ªå­æ®ºä¹‹è€Œäº¡æ­¸ã€‚ äºŒåå…«å¹´ï¼Œç§¦ä¹ƒèˆ‡é½Šã€éŸ“ã€é­å…±æ”»æ¥šï¼Œæ®ºæ¥šå°‡å”çœ›ï¼Œå–æˆ‘é‡ä¸˜è€Œå»ã€‚ äºŒåä¹å¹´ï¼Œç§¦å¾©æ”»æ¥šï¼Œå¤§ç ´æ¥šï¼Œæ¥šè»æ­»è€…äºŒè¬ï¼Œæ®ºæˆ‘å°‡è»æ™¯ç¼ºã€‚ æ‡·ç‹æï¼Œä¹ƒä½¿å¤ªå­ç‚ºè³ªæ–¼é½Šä»¥æ±‚å¹³ã€‚ ä¸‰åå¹´ï¼Œç§¦å¾©ä¼æ¥šï¼Œå–å…«åŸã€‚ ç§¦æ˜­ç‹éºæ¥šç‹æ›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œå§‹å¯¡äººèˆ‡ç‹ç´„ç‚ºå¼Ÿå…„ï¼Œç›Ÿäºé»ƒæ£˜ï¼Œå¤ªå­ç‚ºè³ªï¼Œè‡³é©©ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤ªå­é™µæ®ºå¯¡äººä¹‹é‡è‡£ï¼Œä¸è¬è€Œäº¡å»ï¼Œå¯¡äººèª ä¸å‹æ€’ï¼Œä½¿å…µä¾µå›ç‹ä¹‹é‚Šã€‚ ä»Šèå›ç‹ä¹ƒä»¤å¤ªå­è³ªæ–¼é½Šä»¥æ±‚å¹³ã€‚ å¯¡äººèˆ‡æ¥šæ¥å¢ƒå£¤ç•Œï¼Œæ•…ç‚ºå©šå§»ï¼Œæ‰€å¾ç›¸è¦ªä¹…çŸ£ã€‚ è€Œä»Šç§¦æ¥šä¸é©©ï¼Œå‰‡ç„¡ä»¥ä»¤è«¸ä¾¯ã€‚ å¯¡äººé¡˜èˆ‡å›ç‹æœƒæ­¦é—œï¼Œé¢ç›¸ç´„ï¼Œçµç›Ÿè€Œå»ï¼Œå¯¡äººä¹‹é¡˜ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ•¢ä»¥èä¸‹åŸ·äº‹ã€‚ã€ æ¥šæ‡·ç‹è¦‹ç§¦ç‹æ›¸ï¼Œæ‚£ä¹‹ã€‚ æ¬²å¾€ï¼Œæè¦‹æ¬ºï¼› ç„¡å¾€ï¼Œæç§¦æ€’ã€‚ æ˜­é›æ›°ï¼šã€Œç‹æ¯‹è¡Œï¼Œè€Œç™¼å…µè‡ªå®ˆè€³ã€‚ ç§¦è™ç‹¼ï¼Œä¸å¯ä¿¡ï¼Œæœ‰å¹¶è«¸ä¾¯ä¹‹å¿ƒã€‚ã€ æ‡·ç‹å­å­è˜­å‹¸ç‹è¡Œï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€ŒæŸ°ä½•çµ•ç§¦ä¹‹é©©å¿ƒï¼ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯å¾€æœƒç§¦æ˜­ç‹ã€‚ æ˜­ç‹è©ä»¤ä¸€å°‡è»ä¼å…µæ­¦é—œï¼Œè™Ÿç‚ºç§¦ç‹ã€‚ æ¥šç‹è‡³ï¼Œå‰‡é–‰æ­¦é—œï¼Œé‚èˆ‡è¥¿è‡³å’¸é™½ï¼Œæœç« è‡ºï¼Œå¦‚è•ƒè‡£ï¼Œä¸èˆ‡äº¢ç¦®ã€‚ æ¥šæ‡·ç‹å¤§æ€’ï¼Œæ‚”ä¸ç”¨æ˜­å­è¨€ã€‚ ç§¦å› ç•™æ¥šç‹ï¼Œè¦ä»¥å‰²å·«ã€é»”ä¸­ä¹‹éƒ¡ã€‚ æ¥šç‹æ¬²ç›Ÿï¼Œç§¦æ¬²å…ˆå¾—åœ°ã€‚ æ¥šç‹æ€’æ›°ï¼šã€Œç§¦è©æˆ‘è€Œåˆå½Šè¦æˆ‘ä»¥åœ°ï¼ã€ ä¸å¾©è¨±ç§¦ã€‚ ç§¦å› ç•™ä¹‹ã€‚
In the twenty-seventh year, a Qin minister quarreled privately with the Chu crown prince. The crown prince killed him and fled back to Chu. In the twenty-eighth year, Qin joined with Qi, Han, and Wei to attack Chu. They killed the Chu general Tangmei, captured our Chongqiu, and withdrew. In the twenty-ninth year, Qin attacked Chu again and decisively defeated them. Twenty thousand Chu soldiers died. They killed our general Jingque. King Huai, in fear, sent the crown prince as hostage to Qi to seek peace. In the thirtieth year, Qin attacked Chu again and captured eight cities. Qin Zhao Wang sent a letter to the Chu wang saying: 'In the beginning I agreed with the wang to be brothers. We allied at Huang Ji. The crown prince was hostage. We arrived at harmony. The crown prince insulted and killed one of my important ministers. He offered no apology and fled. I truly cannot contain my anger and have sent troops to invade Your Majesty's borders. Now I hear that Your Majesty has sent the crown prince as hostage to Qi to seek peace. I share borders and territories with Chu. Therefore we formed marriage alliances. Our relationship has been mutually close for a long time. But now Qin and Chu are not on good terms. This gives us no way to command the other lords. I wish to meet Your Majesty at Wuguan, agree face to face, form an alliance, and then depart. This is my sincere wish. I dare to inform the lower servants.' King Huai of Chu read King Zhao's letter and was troubled by it. He desired to go but feared being deceived; He refused to go, fearing Qin's anger. Zhao Ju said: 'Wang, do not go, but mobilize troops to defend yourself. Qin is tiger and wolf. It cannot be trusted. It has the heart to annex the feudal lords.' Huai Wang's son Zi Lan urged the wang to go, saying: 'How can we cut off Qin's harmonious heart!' Thereupon he went to meet King Zhao of Qin. King Zhao deceitfully ordered a general to hide troops at Wuguan, claiming to be the King of Qin. When the King of Chu arrived, they closed Wuguan and proceeded west to Xianyang. He attended at Zhangtai like a vassal minister, receiving no equal ceremony. King Huai of Chu was furious and regretted not heeding Zhao Zi's advice. Qin therefore detained the King of Chu and demanded the cession of the Wu and Qianzhong commanderies. The King of Chu wished to form an alliance. Qin wished to first obtain the territory. The Chu wang was angered and said: 'Qin deceived me and moreover strongly demands land from me!' He no longer agreed to Qin's demands. Qin therefore kept him detained.

æ¥šå¤§è‡£æ‚£ä¹‹ï¼Œä¹ƒç›¸èˆ‡è¬€æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾ç‹åœ¨ç§¦ä¸å¾—é‚„ï¼Œè¦ä»¥å‰²åœ°ï¼Œè€Œå¤ªå­ç‚ºè³ªæ–¼é½Šï¼Œé½Šã€ç§¦åˆè¬€ï¼Œå‰‡æ¥šç„¡åœ‹çŸ£ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒæ¬²ç«‹æ‡·ç‹å­åœ¨åœ‹è€…ã€‚ æ˜­é›æ›°ï¼šã€Œç‹èˆ‡å¤ªå­ä¿±å›°æ–¼è«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œè€Œä»Šåˆå€ç‹å‘½è€Œç«‹å…¶åº¶å­ï¼Œä¸å®œã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒè©èµ´æ–¼é½Šï¼Œé½Šæ¹£ç‹è¬‚å…¶ç›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸è‹¥ç•™å¤ªå­ä»¥æ±‚æ¥šä¹‹æ·®åŒ—ã€‚ã€ ç›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å¯ï¼Œéƒ¢ä¸­ç«‹ç‹ï¼Œæ˜¯å¾æŠ±ç©ºè³ªè€Œè¡Œä¸ç¾©æ–¼å¤©ä¸‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æˆ–æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸ç„¶ã€‚ éƒ¢ä¸­ç«‹ç‹ï¼Œå› èˆ‡å…¶æ–°ç‹å¸‚æ›°ã€äºˆæˆ‘ä¸‹æ±åœ‹ï¼Œå¾ç‚ºç‹æ®ºå¤ªå­ï¼Œä¸ç„¶ï¼Œå°‡èˆ‡ä¸‰åœ‹å…±ç«‹ä¹‹ã€ï¼Œç„¶å‰‡æ±åœ‹å¿…å¯å¾—çŸ£ã€‚ã€ é½Šç‹å’ç”¨å…¶ç›¸è¨ˆè€Œæ­¸æ¥šå¤ªå­ã€‚ å¤ªå­æ©«è‡³ï¼Œç«‹ç‚ºç‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºé ƒè¥„ç‹ã€‚ ä¹ƒå‘Šäºç§¦æ›°ï¼šã€Œè³´ç¤¾ç¨·ç¥éˆï¼Œåœ‹æœ‰ç‹çŸ£ã€‚ã€
The Chu ministers were worried about it and mutually planned, saying: 'Our wang is in Qin and cannot return. They demand land cession, and the crown prince is hostage in Qi. If Qi and Qin combine in plotting, then Chu will have no state.' They then wished to establish one of King Huai's sons who remained in Chu. Zhao Ju said: 'The wang and crown prince are both distressed by the feudal lords, but now again betraying the wang's command to establish his concubine son is not proper.' They then deceived and announced to Qi. Qi Min Wang told his prime minister: 'It would be better to detain the crown prince to seek Chu's Huai Bei.' The prime minister said: 'Not possible. Ying has established a wang. This means we hold an empty hostage and practice unrighteousness in the world.' Some said, 'Not so.' Ying has established a wang. Then bargain with their new wang saying 'give me the lower east state, and I will kill the crown prince for the wang. If not, I will establish him together with the three states.' Then the east state will certainly be obtainable.' The King of Qi finally followed his prime minister's plan and returned the Chu crown prince. Crown Prince Heng arrived and was established as king. He became King Qingxiang. They then informed Qin: 'Relying on the altars and soil spirits, the state has a wang.'

é ƒè¥„ç‹æ©«å…ƒå¹´ï¼Œç§¦è¦æ‡·ç‹ä¸å¯å¾—åœ°ï¼Œæ¥šç«‹ç‹ä»¥æ‡‰ç§¦ï¼Œç§¦æ˜­ç‹æ€’ï¼Œç™¼å…µå‡ºæ­¦é—œæ”»æ¥šï¼Œå¤§æ•—æ¥šè»ï¼Œæ–¬é¦–äº”è¬ï¼Œå–æåäº”åŸè€Œå»ã€‚ äºŒå¹´ï¼Œæ¥šæ‡·ç‹äº¡é€ƒæ­¸ï¼Œç§¦è¦ºä¹‹ï¼Œé®æ¥šé“ï¼Œæ‡·ç‹æï¼Œä¹ƒå¾é–’é“èµ°è¶™ä»¥æ±‚æ­¸ã€‚ è¶™ä¸»çˆ¶åœ¨ä»£ï¼Œå…¶å­æƒ ç‹åˆç«‹ï¼Œè¡Œç‹äº‹ï¼Œæï¼Œä¸æ•¢å…¥æ¥šç‹ã€‚ æ¥šç‹æ¬²èµ°é­ï¼Œç§¦è¿½è‡³ï¼Œé‚èˆ‡ç§¦ä½¿å¾©ä¹‹ç§¦ã€‚ æ‡·ç‹é‚ç™¼ç—…ã€‚ é ƒè¥„ç‹ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ‡·ç‹å’äºç§¦ï¼Œç§¦æ­¸å…¶å–ªäºæ¥šã€‚ æ¥šäººçš†æ†ä¹‹ï¼Œå¦‚æ‚²è¦ªæˆšã€‚ è«¸ä¾¯ç”±æ˜¯ä¸ç›´ç§¦ã€‚ ç§¦æ¥šçµ•ã€‚
In King Qingxiang Heng's first year, Qin demanded territory from King Huai but could not obtain it. Chu established a king to appease Qin. King Zhao of Qin was angered and mobilized troops through Wuguan to attack Chu. He decisively defeated the Chu army, killing 50,000 soldiers, captured Xishi's fifteen cities, and withdrew. In the second year, King Huai of Chu fled and tried to escape home. Qin became aware and blocked the Chu roads. King Huai, in fear, fled to Zhao by a secret route to seek his return home. Lord Zhu of Zhao was in Dai. His son King Hui had recently ascended and was conducting royal affairs. He feared and did not dare receive the King of Chu. The King of Chu wished to flee to Wei. Qin pursued and caught up with him. He then went with the Qin envoy back to Qin. King Huai then fell ill. In King Qingxiang's third year, King Huai died in Qin. Qin returned his remains to Chu. All Chu people pitied him, as if mourning close relatives. The other lords therefore condemned Qin as unjust. Qin and Chu severed relations.

å…­å¹´ï¼Œç§¦ä½¿ç™½èµ·ä¼éŸ“æ–¼ä¼Šé—•ï¼Œå¤§å‹ï¼Œæ–¬é¦–äºŒåå››è¬ã€‚ ç§¦ä¹ƒéºæ¥šç‹æ›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ¥šå€ç§¦ï¼Œç§¦ä¸”ç‡è«¸ä¾¯ä¼æ¥šï¼Œçˆ­ä¸€æ—¦ä¹‹å‘½ã€‚ é¡˜ç‹ä¹‹é£­å£«å’ï¼Œå¾—ä¸€æ¨‚æˆ°ã€‚ã€ æ¥šé ƒè¥„ç‹æ‚£ä¹‹ï¼Œä¹ƒè¬€å¾©èˆ‡ç§¦å¹³ã€‚ ä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œæ¥šè¿å©¦æ–¼ç§¦ï¼Œç§¦æ¥šå¾©å¹³ã€‚
In the sixth year, Qin sent Bai Qi to attack Han at Yique. He achieved a great victory, killing 240,000 soldiers. Qin then sent a letter to the Chu wang: 'Chu has betrayed Qin. Qin will moreover lead the feudal lords to attack Chu and contend for one morning's fate. I wish the wang to prepare his soldiers and obtain one happy battle.' King Qingxiang of Chu was troubled by this and planned to make peace with Qin again. In the seventh year, Chu welcomed a bride from Qin. Qin and Chu were at peace again.

åä¸€å¹´ï¼Œé½Šç§¦å„è‡ªç¨±ç‚ºå¸ï¼› æœˆé¤˜ï¼Œå¾©æ­¸å¸ç‚ºç‹ã€‚
In the eleventh year, Qi and Qin each called themselves emperor; After more than a month, they again abandoned the title of emperor and returned to being kings.

åå››å¹´ï¼Œæ¥šé ƒè¥„ç‹èˆ‡ç§¦æ˜­ç‹å¥½æœƒäºå®›ï¼Œçµå’Œè¦ªã€‚ åäº”å¹´ï¼Œæ¥šç‹èˆ‡ç§¦ã€ä¸‰æ™‰ã€ç‡•å…±ä¼é½Šï¼Œå–æ·®åŒ—ã€‚ åå…­å¹´ï¼Œèˆ‡ç§¦æ˜­ç‹å¥½æœƒæ–¼é„¢ã€‚ å…¶ç§‹ï¼Œå¾©èˆ‡ç§¦ç‹æœƒç©°ã€‚
In the fourteenth year, King Qingxiang of Chu and King Zhao of Qin had a friendly meeting at Wan and formed a peace alliance through marriage. In the fifteenth year, the King of Chu joined with Qin, the three Jin states, and Yan to attack Qi and captured Huaibei. In the sixteenth year, he had a friendly meeting with King Zhao of Qin at Yan. That autumn, he met again with the King of Qin at Rang.

æ•…æ›°ç§¦ç‚ºå¤§é³¥ï¼Œè² æµ·å…§è€Œè™•ï¼Œæ±é¢è€Œç«‹ï¼Œå·¦è‡‚æ“šè¶™ä¹‹è¥¿å—ï¼Œå³è‡‚å‚…æ¥šé„¢éƒ¢ï¼Œè†ºæ“ŠéŸ“é­ï¼Œå‚é ­ä¸­åœ‹ï¼Œè™•æ—¢å½¢ä¾¿ï¼Œå‹¢æœ‰åœ°åˆ©ï¼Œå¥®ç¿¼é¼“é¶´ï¼Œæ–¹ä¸‰åƒé‡Œï¼Œå‰‡ç§¦æœªå¯å¾—ç¨æ‹›è€Œå¤œå°„ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ¬²ä»¥æ¿€æ€’è¥„ç‹ï¼Œæ•…å°ä»¥æ­¤è¨€ã€‚ è¥„ç‹å› å¬èˆ‡èªï¼Œé‚è¨€æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤«å…ˆç‹ç‚ºç§¦æ‰€æ¬ºè€Œå®¢æ­»æ–¼å¤–ï¼Œæ€¨è«å¤§ç„‰ã€‚ ä»Šä»¥åŒ¹å¤«æœ‰æ€¨ï¼Œå°šæœ‰å ±è¬ä¹˜ï¼Œç™½å…¬ã€å­èƒ¥æ˜¯ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šæ¥šä¹‹åœ°æ–¹äº”åƒé‡Œï¼Œå¸¶ç”²ç™¾è¬ï¼ŒçŒ¶è¶³ä»¥è¸´èºä¸­é‡ä¹Ÿï¼Œè€Œåå—å›°ï¼Œè‡£ç«Šç‚ºå¤§ç‹å¼—å–ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯é ƒè¥„ç‹é£ä½¿æ–¼è«¸ä¾¯ï¼Œå¾©ç‚ºå¾ï¼Œæ¬²ä»¥ä¼ç§¦ã€‚ ç§¦èä¹‹ï¼Œç™¼å…µä¾†ä¼æ¥šã€‚
In the eighteenth year, there was a man from Chu who enjoyed shooting returning geese with a weak bow and fine string. King Qingxiang heard of him and summoned him to question him. He replied: 'My small minister's hobby is shooting wild geese and netting ducks with small arrows. What is there sufficient to speak of for the great wang? Moreover, considering Chu's greatness and Your Majesty's wisdom, what you hunt is not merely this. In ancient times, the Three Kings hunted with morality and virtue, the Five Hegemons hunted with the warring states. Therefore Qin, Wei, Yan, and Zhao are wild geese; Qi, Lu, Han, and Wei are green heads; Zou, Fei, Tan, and Pi are like ducks in a net. The others are not worth shooting. Seeing six pairs of birds, what does the wang take? Why doesn't the wang use sages as his bow and brave warriors as his string, and draw and shoot them in timely fashion? These six pairs can be bagged. The pleasure is not just the joy of morning and evening hunts, the gain is not just ducks and geese. If Your Majesty draws his bow in the morning and shoots south of Wei's Daliang, extending the right arm to connect directly with Han, then the roads of the Central Plains will be cut and Shang Cai's commandery will be ruined. Turning to shoot east of Yu, loosening Wei's left elbow and striking outward at Dingtao, then Wei's eastern territories will be abandoned and the two commanderies of Dasong and Fangyu will fall. Moreover Wei has its two arms cut, it is overturned; Striking at Tan head-on, Daliang can be taken. If Your Majesty draws the string at Lantei, waters his horse at the Xi River, and settles Wei's Daliang, this is the joy of one arrow. If Your Majesty truly enjoys hunting and never tires of it, then take the precious bow, sharpen the new string, shoot great birds at the East Sea, return and cover the Long Wall for defense. Shoot East Ju in the morning, Pei Qiu in the evening, add Ji Mo at night, and occupy Wu Dao while looking back. Then the east of the Long Wall will be collected and the north of Mount Tai will be taken. Form borders with Zhao in the west and reach Yan in the north, with the three states spread like cranes. Then the alliance can form without waiting for treaties. Roam your gaze north to Yan's Liaodong and climb south to view Yue's Kuaiji, this is the joy of the second arrow. As for the twelve lords along the Si River, entwine them on the left and sweep them on the rightâ€”they can all be taken in a single morning. Now Qin broke Han as a long worry, obtained row cities but does not dare guard them; Attack Wei without success, strike at Zhao and then fall ill, then Qin and Wei's martial strength will be exhausted. Chu's former lands of Hanzhong, Xi, and Li can be recovered. If Your Majesty takes the precious bow, sharpens the new string, fords the Meng barrier, and waits for Qin to tire, then Shandong and Henan can be united under one rule. Toil the people and rest the multitudes, face south as king. Therefore it is said Qin is a great bird, bearing all under heaven and residing, facing east and standing. Left arm occupies Zhao's southwest, right arm attaches to Chu's Yan and Ying. Chest strikes Han and Wei, hangs head over the Central Plains. The place is already conveniently formed, the situation has land profit. Rousing wings and beating cranes, square three thousand li. Then Qin cannot be obtained by alone beckoning and night shooting.' He wished to provoke King Xiang to anger, so he replied with these words. Xiang Wang therefore summoned and spoke with him, then said: 'Indeed the former wang was deceived by Qin and died as a guest outside. There is no greater resentment. Even a commoner with a grudge can still strike at a great kingdom. White Duke and Wu Zixu are examples. Now Chu's territory is five thousand li, armored one hundred thousand. It is still sufficient to leap in the middle field, but sitting to receive distress. The minister secretly thinks the great wang should not take this.' Thereupon King Qingxiang sent envoys to the other lords, reformed the alliance, intending to attack Qin. Qin heard of this and mobilized troops to attack Chu.

æ¥šæ¬²èˆ‡é½ŠéŸ“é€£å’Œä¼ç§¦ï¼Œå› æ¬²åœ–å‘¨ã€‚ å‘¨ç‹èµ§ä½¿æ­¦å…¬è¬‚æ¥šç›¸æ˜­å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸‰åœ‹ä»¥å…µå‰²å‘¨éƒŠåœ°ä»¥ä¾¿è¼¸ï¼Œè€Œå—å™¨ä»¥å°Šæ¥šï¼Œè‡£ä»¥ç‚ºä¸ç„¶ã€‚ å¤«å¼’å…±ä¸»ï¼Œè‡£ä¸–å›ï¼Œå¤§åœ‹ä¸è¦ªï¼› ä»¥çœ¾è„…å¯¡ï¼Œå°åœ‹ä¸é™„ã€‚ å¤§åœ‹ä¸è¦ªï¼Œå°åœ‹ä¸é™„ï¼Œä¸å¯ä»¥è‡´åå¯¦ã€‚ åå¯¦ä¸å¾—ï¼Œä¸è¶³ä»¥å‚·æ°‘ã€‚ å¤«æœ‰åœ–å‘¨ä¹‹è²ï¼Œéæ‰€ä»¥ç‚ºè™Ÿä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ˜­å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¹ƒåœ–å‘¨å‰‡ç„¡ä¹‹ã€‚ é›–ç„¶ï¼Œå‘¨ä½•æ•…ä¸å¯åœ–ä¹Ÿï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œè»ä¸äº”ä¸æ”»ï¼ŒåŸä¸åä¸åœã€‚ å¤«ä¸€å‘¨ç‚ºäºŒåæ™‰ï¼Œå…¬ä¹‹æ‰€çŸ¥ä¹Ÿã€‚ éŸ“å˜—ä»¥äºŒåè¬ä¹‹çœ¾è¾±æ–¼æ™‰ä¹‹åŸä¸‹ï¼ŒéŠ³å£«æ­»ï¼Œä¸­å£«å‚·ï¼Œè€Œæ™‰ä¸æ‹”ã€‚ å…¬ä¹‹ç„¡ç™¾éŸ“ä»¥åœ–å‘¨ï¼Œæ­¤å¤©ä¸‹ä¹‹æ‰€çŸ¥ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤«æ€¨çµå…©å‘¨ä»¥å¡é¨¶é­¯ä¹‹å¿ƒï¼Œäº¤çµ•æ–¼é½Šï¼Œè²å¤±å¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œå…¶ç‚ºäº‹å±çŸ£ã€‚ å¤«å±å…©å‘¨ä»¥åšä¸‰å·ï¼Œæ–¹åŸä¹‹å¤–å¿…ç‚ºéŸ“å¼±çŸ£ã€‚ ä½•ä»¥çŸ¥å…¶ç„¶ä¹Ÿï¼Ÿ è¥¿å‘¨ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œçµ•é•·è£œçŸ­ï¼Œä¸éç™¾é‡Œã€‚ åç‚ºå¤©ä¸‹å…±ä¸»ï¼Œè£‚å…¶åœ°ä¸è¶³ä»¥è‚¥åœ‹ï¼Œå¾—å…¶çœ¾ä¸è¶³ä»¥å‹å…µã€‚ é›–ç„¡æ”»ä¹‹ï¼Œåç‚ºå¼’å›ã€‚ ç„¶è€Œå¥½äº‹ä¹‹å›ï¼Œå–œæ”»ä¹‹è‡£ï¼Œç™¼è™Ÿç”¨å…µï¼Œæœªå˜—ä¸ä»¥å‘¨ç‚ºçµ‚å§‹ã€‚ æ˜¯ä½•ä¹Ÿï¼Ÿ è¦‹ç¥­å™¨åœ¨ç„‰ï¼Œæ¬²å™¨ä¹‹è‡³è€Œå¿˜å¼’å›ä¹‹äº‚ã€‚ ä»ŠéŸ“ä»¥å™¨ä¹‹åœ¨æ¥šï¼Œè‡£æå¤©ä¸‹ä»¥å™¨è®æ¥šä¹Ÿã€‚ è‡£è«‹è­¬ä¹‹ã€‚ å¤«è™è‚‰è‡Šï¼Œå…¶å…µåˆ©èº«ï¼ŒäººçŒ¶æ”»ä¹‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ è‹¥ä½¿æ¾¤ä¸­ä¹‹éº‹è’™è™ä¹‹çš®ï¼Œäººä¹‹æ”»ä¹‹å¿…è¬æ–¼è™çŸ£ã€‚ è£‚æ¥šä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œè¶³ä»¥è‚¥åœ‹ï¼› è©˜æ¥šä¹‹åï¼Œè¶³ä»¥å°Šä¸»ã€‚ ä»Šå­å°‡ä»¥æ¬²èª…æ®˜å¤©ä¸‹ä¹‹å…±ä¸»ï¼Œå±…ä¸‰ä»£ä¹‹å‚³å™¨ï¼Œåä¸‰ç¿®å…­ç¿¼ï¼Œä»¥é«˜ä¸–ä¸»ï¼Œéè²ªè€Œä½•ï¼Ÿ ã€Šå‘¨æ›¸ã€‹æ›°ã€æ¬²èµ·ç„¡å…ˆã€ï¼Œæ•…å™¨å—å‰‡å…µè‡³çŸ£ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯æ¥šè¨ˆè¼Ÿä¸è¡Œã€‚
Chu wished to ally with Qi and Han to attack Qin, and therefore plotted against Zhou. Zhou Wang Nan sent Wu Gong to tell Chu's prime minister Zhao Zi: 'The three states with troops cut Zhou's suburb land to facilitate transport, and south vessels to honor Chu. The minister thinks not so. Indeed assassinating the common lord and ministering to the hereditary lord, great states will not be close; To coerce the weak with strengthâ€”the small states will not submit. If the great states are not friendly and small states do not submit, you cannot achieve true power. Without true power, you cannot harm the people. Indeed having the reputation of plotting against Zhou is not what to call a banner.' Zhao Zi said: 'As for plotting against Zhou, there is none. Although, why cannot Zhou be plotted against?' He replied: 'An army that is not five times larger does not attack, a city that is not ten times larger does not surround. Indeed, one Zhou is worth twenty Jin states. This is what Your Grace knows. Han once suffered humiliation with 200,000 troops beneath Jin's city walls. The elite soldiers died, the middling soldiers were wounded, yet Jin could not be taken. Your Grace has no hundred Han states to plot against Zhou. This is known throughout the world. Indeed, by antagonizing both Zhou states, you will alienate Zou and Lu. Cutting relations with Qi and losing reputation worldwideâ€”these affairs will be perilous. Indeed, endangering both Zhou states to strengthen Sanchuanâ€”the lands beyond Fangcheng will certainly be weakened for Han. How do you know it is so? Western Zhou's territory, taking the long and short together, does not exceed a hundred li. Though called the world's common lord, dividing its territory is not enough to enrich the state, and gaining its people is not enough to strengthen the army. Even without attacking it, it is called assassinating the ruler. However, rulers who love glory and ministers who love conquest, when issuing orders and deploying troops, never fail to make Zhou their ultimate target. What is this? Seeing the sacrificial vessels there, they desire the vessels to come and forget the wickedness of assassinating the ruler. Now that Han knows the vessels are in Chu, I fear the world will hold Chu as an enemy because of these vessels. Allow me to give an analogy. Indeed, tiger meat is foul, its claws are sharp and its body strong, yet people still hunt it. If a deer in the marsh wears tiger skin, people will attack it ten thousand times more fiercely than they would a real tiger. Splitting Chu's lands is sufficient to enrich the state; Damaging Chu's reputation is sufficient to honor our lord. Now you will desire to execute and harm the world's common lord, dwell with the three dynasties' transmitted vessels, swallow the three pinions and six wings, to high the world lord. If not greedy, what is it? The 'Zhou Book' says 'desire to rise has no first'. Therefore if vessels go south, troops will arrive.' Thereupon Chu's plan was abandoned and not carried out.

In the nineteenth year, Qin attacked Chu. The Chu army was defeated and ceded the lands of Shangyong and Hanbei to Qin. In the twentieth year, Qin general Bai Qi captured our Xiling. In the twenty-first year, Qin general Bai Qi captured our Ying and burned the tombs of the former kings at Yiling. King Xiang of Chu's army scattered. He ceased fighting and withdrew northeast to defend at Chen city. In the twenty-second year, Qin recaptured our Wu and Qianzhong commanderies.

In the twenty-third year, King Xiang gathered troops from the eastern territories, obtaining more than one hundred thousand men. He recaptured to the west the fifteen cities along the Yangtze that Qin had taken, made them into a commandery, and resisted Qin. In the twenty-seventh year, he sent thirty thousand men to help the three Jin states attack Yan. He again made peace with Qin, sending the crown prince as a hostage there. Chu sent the Left Minister to attend the crown prince in Qin.

In the thirty-sixth year, King Qingxiang fell ill. The crown prince fled back to Chu. In autumn, King Qingxiang died. Crown Prince Xiong Yuan succeeded him, becoming King Kaolie. King Kaolie appointed the Left Minister as Prime Minister, enfeoffed him with Wu, and gave him the title Lord Chunshen.

In King Kaolie's first year, he ceded Zhou to Qin to make peace. At this time, Chu grew increasingly weak.

In the sixth year, Qin besieged Handan. Zhao urgently appealed to Chu for help. Chu sent General Jing Yang to rescue Zhao. In the seventh year, he reached Xinzhong. The Qin troops withdrew. In the twelfth year, King Zhao of Qin died. The King of Chu sent Lord Chunshen to offer condolences and perform sacrifices in Qin. In the sixteenth year, King Zhuangxiang of Qin died. King Zhao Zheng ascended the throne of Qin. In the twenty-second year, he joined the other lords in attacking Qin, but the campaign was unsuccessful and he withdrew. Chu moved its capital eastward to Shouchun and renamed it Ying.

In the twenty-fifth year, King Kaolie died. His son Han ascended the throne, becoming King You. Li Yuan assassinated Lord Chunshen. In King You's third year, Qin and Wei attacked Chu. King Ai reigned for more than two months before his half-brother Fuchu's followers assassinated him and installed Fuchu as king. That same year, Qin captured King Qian of Zhao.

In King Fuchu's first year, Crown Prince Dan of Yan sent Jing Ke to assassinate the King of Qin. In the second year, Qin sent a general to attack Chu, inflicting a major defeat on the Chu army and capturing more than ten cities. In the third year, Qin destroyed Wei. In the fourth year, Qin general Wang Jian defeated our army at Qi and killed General Xiang Yan.

å¤ªå²å…¬æ›°ï¼šæ¥šéˆç‹æ–¹æœƒè«¸ä¾¯æ–¼ç”³ï¼Œèª…é½Šæ…¶å°ï¼Œä½œç« è¯è‡ºï¼Œæ±‚å‘¨ä¹é¼ä¹‹æ™‚ï¼Œå¿—å°å¤©ä¸‹ï¼› åŠé¤“æ­»äºç”³äº¥ä¹‹å®¶ï¼Œç‚ºå¤©ä¸‹ç¬‘ã€‚ æ“è¡Œä¹‹ä¸å¾—ï¼Œæ‚²å¤«ï¼ å‹¢ä¹‹æ–¼äººä¹Ÿï¼Œå¯ä¸æ…èˆ‡ï¼Ÿ æ£„ç–¾ä»¥äº‚ç«‹ï¼Œå¬–æ·«ç§¦å¥³ï¼Œç”šä¹å“‰ï¼Œå¹¾å†äº¡åœ‹ï¼
The Grand Historian said: When Chu Ling Wang was just assembling the feudal lords at Shen, executing Qi Qing Feng, building Zhang Hua Tai, and seeking the Zhou nine tripods, his ambitions were small for the world; He ended up starving to death at Shen Hai's home, becoming the laughingstock of the world. His conduct and behavior were not obtained. How sorrowful! As for power in relation to people, can one not be careful? Qi Ji was established through disorder. He favored and was lewd with Qin women. How extreme! He nearly perished the state again!
